key_title: Key to the genera of Myrtaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Myrtaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Myrtaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Fruit a 1-seeded succulent berry; tree of sheltered gullies in eastern Victoria
Fruit a dry loculicidal capsule or indehiscent nut (or in prostrate, western Kunzea pomifera, a several-seeded, fleshy capsule)
[link through]
Stamens fused in 5 bundles opposite the petals
Stamens not fused in bundles, usually completely free, rarely fused in irregular bundles opposite sepals
Flowers sessile, aggregated in heads or spikes
Flowers pedicellate, aggregated in cymes; East Gippsland only
[link through]
Flower buds not covered by an operculum
Flower buds covered by a deciduous operculum composed of fused perianth segments
Leaves opposite
Leaves alternate
Shrubs to 5 m high; leaves mostly less than 3 cm long and 7 mm wide
Trees to 30 m high; leaves mostly more than 4 cm long and 2 cm wide
Ovary 2- or 3-celled; fruit a capsule, dehiscing by terminal slits (except in fleshy-fruited Kunzea pomifera); seeds numerous
Ovary 1-celled; fruit small, indehiscent; seed usually solitary
Stamens mostly longer than petals
Stamens all shorter than petals
Leaves normally more than 2 mm wide; flowers 2 or more in axillary umbels; ovary 3-celled
Leaves normally less than 2 mm wide; flowers solitary in leaf axils (rarely with 2 or 3 flowers in axils); ovary 2- or 3-celled
At least some anthers united in bundles opposite sepals; escaped from cultivation
Anthers not united into bundles
Leaves mostly 3–8 mm long, more or less terete, tapered to a recurved apical point; ovary 3-celled; north-western Victoria
Leaves flat or thick, not tapered to a recurved apical point, if ever terete then apical point straight and ovary 2-celled
[link through]
Flowers sessile
Flowers pedicellate
Petals pinkish; bracteoles subopposite or alternate, persistent; ovary 3-celled; seeds reniform, arillate
Petals white or pink; bracteoles opposite, deciduous or absent; ovary 2- or 3-celled; seeds angular, or if reniform then exarillate
[link through]
Stamens 10, alternating with 10 minute staminodes; style long and exserted; far east and far west only
Stamens 5 or 10 (rarely 12), opposite petals and/or sepals, staminodes absent; style shortly exserted

Leaves less than 5 mm long, more or less trigonous; stamens 5 and opposite petals, or 10 (rarely 12) and opposite petals and sepals; anthers opening by longitudinal slits, connective gland small, subglobose

Leaves mostly more than 5 mm long, flat or slightly concave above; stamens usually 5 and opposite sepals; anthers opening by pores, connective gland prominent, clavate or urceolate; Grampians and Gippsland only
[link through]
Leaves with raised oil glands, eventually glabrous; flowers white or cream; fruit woody, strongly ribbed
Leaves white-tomentose on lower surface; flowers reddish or crimson; fruit white-tomentose, not woody or strongly ribbed
[link through]
Sepals persistent, often tipped by a long awn; ovary 1-celled
Sepals persistent or non-persistent, never awn-tipped; ovary 2–5-celled
Flowers aggregated in spike-like conflorescences (bottlebrush); sepals not persistent; petals inconspicuous; capsules quite sessile, encircling stems and persisting for many years
Flowers solitary in leaf axils or in heads (rarely in a short spike); sepals often persistent; petals usually conspicuous; capsules, if persisting, not sheathing stems, usually pedicellate
Most stamens considerably longer than the petals
Stamens shorter, or scarcely longer, than petals
Flowers solitary or in loose clusters; native plants
Flowers in dense heads in leaf axils or terminal on short axillary shoots; cultivated plants
Fruits (valves and hypanthium) woody, usually persistent; seeds linear, surface striate; sepals deciduous or persistent in fruit
Fruits thin-walled and deciduous or semi-persistent and the hypanthium somewhat succulent; seeds ovate, surface reticulate; sepals persistent in fruit
Leaves less than 4 cm long; stamens 10 or fewer, 1 opposite each sepal and petal; petals circular, distinctly clawed
Leaves mostly more than 4.5 cm long; stamens more than 11, usually in groups of 3 or more and only opposite sepals; petals obovate not or hardly clawed
[link through]
Inflorescences axillary, of single flowers, umbels or small panicles, if ever terminal then leaf venation not as below; leaves usually with a distinct eucalyptus odour
Inflorescences of terminal panicles; adult leaves with numerous, prominent, pinnate side veins at wide angle to midrib, not or only faintly smelling of eucalyptus (sometimes lemon-scented)
